snippet: Even as the mediator, Lakhdar Brahimi, expressed frustration over stalled talks, France’s foreign minister accused the Syrian government of carrying out chemical attacks after signing a treaty.
abstract: International efforts to end the war in Syria falter further as United Nations mediator Lakhdar Brahimi resigns his post and France cites evidence that Syrian government has used chemical weapons more than a dozen times since signing treaty banning them; events come amid signs of disarray in Western coalition and concern that diplomatic solution may not emerge.

byline.original: By SOMINI SENGUPTA and MICHAEL R. GORDON
byline.contributor: Somini Sengupta reported from the United Nations, and Michael R. Gordon from Washington. Alan Cowell contributed reporting from London, and Rick Gladstone from New York.

lead_paragraph: Even as the mediator, Lakhdar Brahimi, expressed frustration over stalled talks, France’s foreign minister accused the Syrian government of carrying out chemical attacks after signing a treaty.

headline.main: U.N. Mediator on Syria Quits; French Envoy Says Chemicals Were Used
headline.print_headline: U.N. Mediator on Syria Quits; Envoy Says Chemicals Were Used

keywords.value: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
